Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Self-Organizing Systems: Engineering and Understanding Robust Collective Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates self-organizing systems: (1) how to engineer self-repairing distributed computing systems, (2) how to understand robustness in multicellular biology. The goal is to provide
a fundamental understanding of the basic principles underlying robustness and adaptability in multicellular biological systems, and demonstrate how these principles can be applied to computing systems.
Many areas in computer science critically depend on the ability to easily program robust collective behavior from massively-parallel substrates, from traditional computer networks to modular robotics.
This research will significantly improve our ability to design computing systems that self-organize, self-heal, and adapt. This research will also impact biology by providing novel insights into
tissue development and disease.

This research has two main thrusts: (1) using insights from self-maintaining and self-healing behavior in multicellular organs, such as the heart, to design algorithms for embedded distributed systems, such as wireless sensor networks (2) developing computational models of cell level behavior, based on experimental data, that can predict novel system-level properties in epithelial tissues. These efforts will contribute to a deeper understanding of how global robustness is achieved from the decentralized interactions of large
numbers of identically-programmed, unreliable agents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological systems, from multicellular organisms to social insects, get tremendous mileage from the cooperation of vast numbers of cheap, unreliable, and limited individuals. Many engineered systems also share similar goals, from computer networks to robot swarms. In these systems, a large numbers of simple agents must cooperate to produce complex and robust global behavior. 

This NSF Career project was aimed at developing a fundamental and mathematical understanding for natural and engineered self-organizing multi-agent systems. 

We investigated several different systems:

1. Natural self-assembly in the fruit fly wing:: We developed a series of mathematical models to understand cell division in epithelial tissues; these tissues form many structures from skin to lining of organs and are critical in early embryo development. We have shown that growing tissue can be thought of as a self-organizing network that  expands through the creation of new nodes and edges via cell division. Our models have led to several insights (1) the tissue network converges to a robust cell shape distribution even though cell division has significant randomness (2) the equilibrium cell shape distribution can be  used as a signature that reveals key properties about the tissue (3) many natural systems show a highly conserved cell shape distribution. This work was done in close collboration with experimental biologists, and many predictions were validated through experiments on the fruit fly wing.

2. Engineering synchronization:: We explored models of biological synchronization, inspired by  fireflies and heart cells, and applied them to wireless sensor networks. Our findings have shown how synchronization can be used to create robust networks that easily adapt to changes.

3. Engineering self-repairing pattern formation:: Inspired by pattern formation in early embryo development, we developed theortical models for understanding the relationship between a cell's individual behavior and the possible resulting global patterns. For example, we showed how certain patterns are impossible to form if cells have only limited memory. We also showed how the theory can be used to create global-to-local compilers for classes of pattern formation problems.

3. Robot testbed for studying self-organization: We developed a testbed for studying self-organizing systems, called the Kilobot testbed. This swarm of 1000+ low-cost robots allow us as well as other researchers to study algorithms for large-scale mobile networks, robot swarm coordination, and bio-inspired collective intelligence. This testbed was partially funded by this grant as well as the Harvard Wyss Institute and the NSF Expeditions program. The design was released open-source and is now also cmmercially aviable through an educational robotics company.
